When I was in U the best fit line was calculated by noticing that if you add the deviations you might get even zeros if others are positive and others negative. So you can't just add naked deviations. So our teacher showed that if you take the absolute values and try that the derivation of the line is horrible mess. So next best way to get out of negative deviations is to square them and that was easy calculation. So, that was very illuminating excercise.

The beauty of calculus is that the machinery itself is not complicated, there are limited tools, but the scope and application has been as wide as humanity's imagination. You just have to develop the intuition and everything is easy then, good lectures by OCW, as always

Thank you so much MIT !!! I love all of your videos. However, I was really confused by all of the completing the square stuff and complicated inequalities and the like. After doing a bit of thinking, I realized there is no need to do all of that. You can simply look at the cross sections in the x and y directions respectively at the critical point and see if they are min or maxes. If they are both min, then its a min, if both max its a max, if one max and one min, then its a saddle. Lots of love for you, xxxx.

PussyIsHere   I am not hating on chalk! I am hating on the style of cleaning.  The proper way to clean a blackboard is to use a wet eraser, and subsequently a device that removes the water. If you're good, you can do both at the same time.  I knew a prof in my university who could clean a giant black board in about 20 seconds. There is zero dust, you can write on it immediately, and it looks *perfect*. It's like the blackboard has just been installed. (The prof was/is far worse than this one, but man the style of cleaning blackboard is SO much better.)

+Ярик Троф That is because you want to obtain average deviation and from that determine when the average deviation is the smallest. (Average distance of the point given by the data from the predicted point)
It makes it convex and the numbers are all positive too.

Well, if you use just the difference the sum (and the average difference) will be close to 0 if the data really does behave similiar to a line. You can also use the absolute difference but it is rarely used in statistics because sum of squared distances (variance) and the square root of its mean (so called 'standard deviation') prove to be more convinient for data with normal distribution.

To drive the point further, you need to understand that the distribution of different data values around the line will actually behavel ike a normal one - around a predicted value along the line whic will be a mean of its distribution. So by minimizing the squared difference we will get the significantly thinner expected distribution along every point on a line, thus making a very good approximation of the value.

Because square deviation it can be applied on all kinds of polynomial behaviors (linear behavior, quadratic behavior and so on), ordinary one can be applied just when your experimental data has a linear behavior.
